The War Cabinet had before them a Memorandum fromthe American Ambassador to the Prime Minister, stating that president Roosevelt asked that additional United States forces should be sent as quickly as possible to Newfoundland, Bermuda andTrinidad, to provide against the risk of attack by surface naval vessels. Attached to his Memorandum was a Minute by the Chiefsof Staff recommending acceptance of these proposals (W.P. (41) 81).The Prime Minister said that he was entirely in favour ofsignifying our concurrence in these proposals. This view wasshared by all members of the War Cabinet.The War Cabinet -Agreed that the proposals in Mr. Winant's memorandum should be accepted, and approved a suggestion that detailsshould be arranged as follows(a) As regards Newfoundland, by the U.S.A.-CanadianDefence Board, the Government of Newfoundlandbeing informed.(&) As regards Bermuda and Trinidad, by the U.S.A.authorities and the Commander-in-Chief of theAmerican West Indies Station.The Prime Minister undertook to inform Mr. Winant; theSecretary of State for Dominion Affairs to communicate with the Governments of Canada and Newfoundland; andthe Secretary of State for the Colonies with the Govern-ments of Trinidad and Bermuda.Naval, Militaryand air operations.(previous reference:W.M. (41) 36thConclusions,Minute 1.)MilitaryOperations.2. The War Cabinet were given the latest information as tothe military situation in the Balkans and Middle East.In Cyrenaica it was believed that our infantry formations had completed their withdrawal to the Tobruk area. The PrimeMinister thought that there were signs that the rush of the enemy'sadvance was exhausting itself and that the situation gave less cause for anxiety. Particulars were given as to the dispositions of our troops.In the Balkans the Greek troops were holding out at the RoupelPass and on the Nestos Line. To the west of the Roupel Pass theposition was rather confused, but it seemed that the Yugoslav troops had given ground on the Strumica Valley. The German forcesadvancing via Kumanovo had captured Skoplje. The Yugoslavforces which had entered Albania might be taken in the rear by this force.The War Cabinet took note of this statement.Air Raids.Damage.(previous references:W.M. (41) 31stConclusions,Minute 4,and 32ndConclusions,Minute 3.)3. The Minister of Aircraft Production said that serious damage had been suffered by aircraft factories at Rochester andBelfast on the previous night.The War Cabinet took note of this statement.Great George Street, S.W. 1,April 8, 1941.
